The International Space Station (ISS) is clearly an example of the phenomenal collaboration between skilled visionary technicians focuses utilizing and developing dynamic technologies.

In my opinion, the on going progress and/or failures have not particularly been mainstream communicated to the general public.

Unless one is specifically seeking to become a part/member of the program, the only information about the ISS which is available to the general public comes through obscure programs such as this one, SmarterEveryDay.

Please understand that calling this vlog “obscure” is stated with great respect to everyone involved with organizing and publicizing this platform. All I’m attempting to express is there is very, very little information publicized or available. I believe that the ISS community should have a delegated team that compiles information about the ISS’s developments and activities. And then, publicizes the information into layman’s terms for better understanding.

The “SmarterEveryDay” program with its producer and narrator, Destin Wilson Sandlin, who is an American engineer and science communicator provides a phenomenal program. Unfortunately and, again in my opinion, provides the ONLY source that has shed light on the topic the ISS. THANK YOU SIR! However, there needs to be much more information available.

Would you go to the Moon in this joke?

The Lunar Module Challenger—the 17.9 x 14 x 13.3-foot spider spacecraft that took Apollo 17 astronauts Eugene Cernan and Harrison Schmitt to the surface of the Moon while Command Module Pilot Roland Evans orbited above them. If it looks fragile to you is because it was fragile. Or better said, strong enough to carry its mission but too fragile to fly anywhere but in space or the Moon.

At the time, the priority was to make it as light as humanly possible and give enough space to the astronauts inside, as well as any tools they needed (and to bring rocks from its surface on its way back to the Command Module). The ascent stage—which you can see in the photo—was only 10,300 pounds including its frame, engines, fuel, crew seats and the on-board computer. To give you an idea on how fragile this amazing spacecraft was, its walls were only 0.012 inches thick (0.03 centimeters) at some points. That's as thick as a paper sheet.

According to Google - The International Space Station travels in orbit around Earth at a speed of roughly 17,150 miles per hour, (which is approx. 5 miles per second!). To put this into perspective means that the Space Station orbits Earth (and sees a sunrise) once every 92 minutes! 

Not only that, but "they" also claim that the ISS (which is about the size of a football filed) can be seen by the naked eye from 240 miles above the earth. To put this into perspective . . we have a jet airliner (which is approx. half the size of a football field) that flies less than 10 miles above the earth and that same jet can barely be seen at that distance.  Now if that jet can barely be seen at 10 miles, how could the ISS be seen at 240 miles and traveling at the speed of 17K mph?  It's NOT possible.  The reality is that they show us cartoon pictures and not real pics.  Blessings!

Thanks Destin for this, Not only did you create a unique radar for this video. But this is sort of a holy grail to understanding how the ISS is laid out. It opens up a lot more questions though. Such as where is the reaction control system located, and what propellant does it use? And where are the nozzles? Every single little movement in the ISS has to be compensated for, otherwise all it would take is somebody to walk too fast and bump into a wall to cause the entire ISS to be moved out of position.

I am also dying to understand the airlock systems. I noticed in this mockup those airlocks sometimes look like they might seal. And others look like they are have been blocked by the ceiling racks. And others don't even look like they are functional.
And in many rooms just doesn't see like there is anything at all. If you ever look at a submarine, the airlocks are frequent. In the ISS if you shut any airlock, everybody would be unable to get to through to vast portions of the ISS since it has a main corridor. Considering we are talking about Micrometeorites, extreme temperature changes on a thin metal sheathing, and a zillion gadgets with plumbing in/out of this sheathing. I would expect getting air leaks is the #1 safety issue. If you are looking for a unique video to make, make one on how the airlock safety procedures work. how they expect to get to the other modules, And to operate those airlocks for us.
